awd_titl_txt: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) is a top-tier venue for quick and wide dissemination of cutting-edge research results in computer security applications. The conference achieves this by hosting several technical sessions, workshops, training sessions, keynotes by distinguished speakers, case studies, panels, national interest discussions, work-in-progress talks and poster sessions. The 2019 ACSAC conference will consist of approximately 48 technical papers across a wide spectrum of computer security and privacy domains. The hard topic theme of the 2019 conference is "Deployable and Impactful Security." The conference agenda explores some of the most intriguing and pressing challenges in the discipline, highlighting open avenues for further work in these areas. Participation in the conference is thus a valuable opportunity to students and is an important part of graduate education in cyber-security.

This award provides travel support to encourage participation in the 2019 Annual Computer Security Applications Conference by students who would normally find it difficult to attend. Criteria for selection include evidence of a serious interest in the field as demonstrated by statement of research, CV showing research output, coursework and/or project experience, etc. Organizers encourage participation of women and students from other under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The Annual Computer Security Applications Conference (ACSAC) is a top-tier academic security conference whose core mission is investigating practical solutions for computer security technology. Run by the Applied Computer Security Associates (ACSA), it brings together the foremost minds in academia, industry, and government to address the most pressing problems in applied computer security, as well as discuss seminal works in information security. ACSAC is a highly competitive, peer-reviewed conference. The conference program is comprised of two days of pre-conference workshops, and three days of technical paper sessions, keynote talks, panels, a 'works-in-progress' session, and a poster session. A complete description of the conference can be found on the ACSAC website at https://www.acsac.org/2019/ and a copy of the full program can be found at https://www.acsac.org/2019/program/final/.

The NSF Student Travel Grant for ACSAC 2019 provided conference registration fees and travel support for U.S.-based undergraduate and graduate students to attend the ACSAC conference held in San Juan, Puerto Rico on December 9-13, 2019.

NSF student funding supported registration fees and a portion of travel costs for students from U.S. educational institutions. Separate funding from the Charles Koch Institute (CKI) and ACSA supported registration fees and a portion of travel costs for additional students from U.S. educational institutions, students from international institutions, and recipients of Scholarships for Women Studying Information Security (SWSIS), which provides assistance to women studying for their bachelor's or master's degrees in fields relating to information security. CKI and ACSA funding also supported registration fees for students from U.S. minority-serving educational institutions to attend the TracerFIRE workshop, an interactive, group-based forensic and incident response exercise.

The attached table provides overall statistics on ACSAC 2019 attendance, technical papers, and supported students, including degrees pursued, active roles in the conference, women, and members of underrepresented groups.

A key goal of ACSAC 2019 was to provide opportunities for student education, as well as training and professional development. Students participating in the conference gained valuable insight into current research. Similarly, the workshops offered students additional insight into hot topic areas. A number of students shared their research with other conference participants by presenting technical papers or a poster. Attendees learned from the students and made connections that could lead to future employment. The invited keynote speeches gave conference attendees leading experts' perspective on applying security to difficult technical problems.

ACSAC is committed to increasing the quality and quantity of women and members of underrepresented groups in cybersecurity education and ultimately the cybersecurity profession. In support of this commitment, ACSAC 2019 worked proactively to recruit members of underrepresented groups and women from HBCU's, national societies and associations, universities in Puerto Rico and US Virgin Islands, the GREPSEC series of workshops, and the SWSIS program. This resulted in supporting a number of members of underrepresented groups and women as well as students from local universities in Puerto Rico.

The ACSAC conference is widely publicized and open to all members of the international information security community. The conference proceedings were published by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) and are available via the ACM Digital Library at https://dl.acm.org/doi/proceedings/10.1145/3359789. The proceedings were also made freely available via the ACSAC website at https://www.acsac.org/2019/program/papers/.

ACSAC greatly appreciates NSF's support. The conference helps feed the development of new computer and network security technologies and their application to solve address critical security, resilience, and privacy challenges in today's information security systems. By promoting and supporting student participation, the conference facilitates education and interaction and helps develop and groom the next generation of security professionals.

 


Last Modified: 07/08/2022
Modified by: David Balenson
